global_flags.description: Causes  debugfs  to  open the device using Direct I/O, bypassing the buffer cache.  Note that some Linux devices, notably  device mapper as of this writing, do not support Direct I/O.
debugfs  to execute the single command request, and then exit.
print the version number of debugfs and exit.

the  use of the given block size (in bytes) for the file system, rather than detecting the correct block  size  automati‐ cally.  (This option is rarely needed; it is used primarily when the file system is extremely badly damaged/corrupted.)

Specifies  that the file system should be opened in catastrophic mode, in which the inode and group bitmaps  are  not  read  ini‐ tially.   This  can  be useful for file systems with significant corruption, but because of this, catastrophic  mode  forces  the file system to be opened read-only.
with  the  -i  option,  specifies  that data_source_device should be used when reading blocks not found in the  ext2  image file.  This includes data, directory, and indirect blocks.
debugfs  to  read in commands from cmd_file, and execute them.  When debugfs is finished  executing  those  commands,  it will exit.

Specifies  that  device represents an ext2 image file created by the e2image program.  Since the ext2 image  file  only  contains the  superblock, block group descriptor, block and inode alloca‐ tion bitmaps, and the inode table, many  debugfs  commands  will not  function properly.  Warning: no safety checks are in place, and debugfs may fail in interesting ways if commands such as ls, dump, etc. are tried without specifying  the  data_source_device using the -d option.  debugfs is a debugging tool.  It has rough edges!
Disables  metadata  checksum  verification.  This should only be used if you believe the metadata to be correct despite the  com‐ plaints of e2fsprogs.

the  file  system  superblock  to be read from the given block number, instead of using the primary  superblock  (located at  an  offset of 1024 bytes from the beginning of the file sys‐ tem).  If you specify the -s option, you must also  provide  the blocksize  of  the file system via the -b option.   (This option is rarely needed; it is used primarily when the file  system  is extremely badly damaged/corrupted.)
Specifies  that  the  file system should be opened in read-write mode.  Without this option, the file system is opened  in  read- only mode.

old  contents of  the  block to an undo file.  This undo file can be used with e2undo(8) to restore the old contents of the file system  should something  go  wrong.   If  the  empty  string  is passed as the undo_file argument, the undo file will  be  written  to  a  file named  debugfs-device.e2undo  in the directory specified via the E2FSPROGS_UNDO_DIR environment variable.

subcommands.name: Bit-flip
subcommands.description: portions  of  the physical block_num.  If -f is given, then block_num is a logical block relative to the start of file‐ spec.

subcommands.name: Change
subcommands.description: the  current working directory of the debugfs process to directory on the native file system.

subcommands.name: Copy
subcommands.description: the  contents  of source_file into a newly-created file in the file system named out_file.

subcommands.name: Create
subcommands.description: a link named dest_file which is a hard link to filespec. Note this does not adjust the inode reference counts.

subcommands.name: Deallocate
subcommands.description: the  inode  filespec and its blocks.  Note that this does not remove any directory entries (if any)  to  this  inode. See the rm(1) command if you wish to unlink a file.

subcommands.name: Display
subcommands.description: the  multiple-mount  protection (mmp) field values.  If mmp_block is specified then verify and dump the MMP values  from the  given  block number, otherwise use the s_mmp_block field in the superblock to locate and use the existing MMP block.

subcommands.name: Dump
subcommands.description: the  file system block given by block_num in hex and ASCII format to the console.  If the -f option is specified, the block number is relative to the start of the given filespec.   If  the

subcommands.name: Find
subcommands.description: a  free  inode and allocate it.  If present, dir specifies the inode number of the directory which the inode is to  be  lo‐ cated.   The second optional argument mode specifies the permis‐ sions of the new inode.  (If the directory bit  is  set  on  the mode,  the  allocation routine will function differently.)  Also available as ffi.

subcommands.name: List
subcommands.description: the  extended attributes associated with the file filespec to standard output.

subcommands.name: Mark
subcommands.description: the  file system as dirty, so that the superblocks will be written on exit.  Additionally,  clear  the  superblock's  valid flag, or set it if -clean is specified.

subcommands.name: Modify
subcommands.description: the  inode specified by filespec so that the inode field field has value value.  The list of valid inode fields which can be set via this command can be displayed by using  the  command: set_inode_field -l Also available as sif.

subcommands.name: Note
subcommands.description: that this does not fully initialize all of the data struc‐ tures; to do this, use the mke2fs(8) program.  This  is  just  a call  to the low-level library, which sets up the superblock and block descriptors.

subcommands.name: Print
subcommands.description: a  listing of the inodes which use the one or more blocks specified on the command line.

subcommands.name: Set
subcommands.description: the superblock field field to value.  The list of valid su‐ perblock fields which can be set via this command  can  be  dis‐ played  by  using the command: set_super_value -l Also available as ssv.

subcommands.name: Test
subcommands.description: if  the  block  number block is marked as allocated in the block bitmap.  If the optional argument count is  present,  then count blocks starting at block number block will be tested.

subcommands.name: The
subcommands.description: -S option causes logdump to print the contents of the jour‐ nal superblock.

subcommands.name: Unlink
subcommands.description: pathname.   If this causes the inode pointed to by path‐ name to have no other references,  deallocate  the  file.   This command functions as the unlink() system call.

subcommands.name: help
subcommands.description: Print a list of commands understood by debugfs.

subcommands.name: ical
subcommands.description: block  start_block and end_block, inclusive.  If end_block is not supplied, this function maps until it runs  out  of  free disk  blocks or the maximum file size is reached.  Existing map‐ pings are left alone.

subcommands.name: pwd
subcommands.description: Print the current working directory.

subcommands.name: quit
subcommands.description: Quit debugfs
